summary: Obsessively punctual FedEx executive Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) is en route to an assignment in Malaysia when his plane crashes over the Pacific Ocean during a storm. The sole survivor of the flight, Chuck washes ashore on a deserted island. When his efforts to sail away and contact help fail, Chuck learns how to survive on the island, where he remains for years, accompanied by only his handmade volleyball friend, Wilson. Will Chuck ever return to civilization and reunite with his loved ones?

reviews.content: The themes of resilience, hope, and the human spirit are explored in a thought-provoking and moving way, making Cast Away a must-see film for any fan of drama and adventure.

Cast Away isn't a bad movie or anything, it's just a tough sell in 2023. It's very 2000. Tom Hanks is good in it but the production and direction of blockbusters from this era carry a familiar cadence to one another outside of a few stand outs. This still has family friendly 90s undertones without it being a family movie at heart. It's a tough thing to put your finger on exactly, but it certainly detracts from what would be a grittier situation than is portrayed. I'm not exactly sure what it is about movies like American Beauty or Erin Brockovich that help them to age better but Cast Away just feels old. 

That all said, it has an interesting spin on the stranded on an island schtick. Particularly that it handles his re-entry to society and it isn't all roses. It's probably too long, but it's still an overall enjoyable experience.

Unfortunately, Chuck is just a complete fucking idiot. It's incredibly frustrating to watch him make even the most basic of decisions while trying to survive on the island. He makes irrational choices and wastes resources in a completely unbelievable way. I get that he's supposed to be portrayed as an isolated person with no life experience outside of his devotion to FedEx (for some fucking reason), but a lot of this stuff is just basic common sense that ruins the immersion of the film.

Far from perfect, this movie is saved by its direction and by Hanks's performance.

The sole survivor of a plane crash at sea, Fed Ex employee Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) finds himself alone on a deserted tropical island with little hope of rescue. Hanks is great in the lead role, the cinematography is excellent, and the story moves along at a nice pace for the first 100 minutes or so.  However, the final thirty minutes, most of which probably should have been left on the editing room floor, is Hollywood soppiness at its worst, especially the reunion scene, one of the most shameless attempts to tug at the heartstrings ever committed to celluloid.  Other than that, it is well worth a watch.

Robert Zemeckis' "Cast Away" is an intense, profound and heartwarming survival drama that showcases Tom Hanks at his absolute best. With his twelfth feature, director Robert Zemeckis crafted a powerful drama about a FedEx employee that struggles to survive on a South Pacific island. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to humanize the lives of stranded plane-crash victims, but he pulled it off seamlessly. Using spellbinding cinematography, Zemeckis draws viewers into the world of a resourceful FedEx employee stranded on an isolated island. From intimate close-ups to stunning establishing shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the film's setting. Zemeckis showcases immense technical control over the sound design, locations and visual effects, immersing viewers into the desolate setting. William Broyles Jr.'s screenplay is also sensational, and effectively uses minimal dialogue to convey the isolation faced by the main character. It is hard to not praise the phenomenal performances from the cast. Tom Hanks delivers one of the finest performances of his career as Chuck Noland. With mesmerizing expressions, he conveys the angst, desperation and resourcefulness of a man that is forced to use his instincts to survive on a stranded island. Although "Cast Away" is undeniably an unforgettable survival drama, ultimately it is not a flawless film. At nearly two and a half hours, it suffers from a lengthy running-time that tests the viewer's patience. Nevertheless, fans of survival dramas will definitely enjoy "Cast Away" and so will movie-goers seeking heartfelt entertainment. As someone fortunate enough to have never been stranded on an island, it made me cherish my life and feel grateful for things that I too often take for granted.

Robert Zemeckis' Cast Away is a heartbreaking tale saturated with subtleties in both the story it tells and it's surroundings. Zemeckis' attention to the architecture and detail of every scene makes the film one of the greatest I've ever seen. Everything from the main protagonist's name, Chuck Noland (Who literally has "no land" around him) to subtle symbols and facts scattered throughout make this film a true masterpiece of production.

In its content, Cast Away shows the psychological strain that can be caused by prolonged isolation. This becomes more apparent as we follow Chuck Through his tragedy. Chuck gives his girlfriend Kelly a present on Christmas before boarding a plane and asks her to only open it on new year's, he then promises he'll be there with her when she does. A storm takes down Chuck's plane in a spectacular scene with warning lights flashing, thunder roaring, lightning striking and darkness dominating the camera frame. Chuck almost drowns with the plane, but his lifeboat is released just in time and he's stuck with nothing but a lifeboat. He makes it to a deserted island, where he spends the next four years. soon after his arrival, we start seeing FedEx packages washing up on the island. In a place where no one can reach Chuck, his job does. 

In one of these packages, he finds a volleyball sent as a gift to "Johnny" from his grandfather. After failing to start a fire and injuring his hand in the process, Noland throws the ball in a fit of anger and imprints a bloody hand on it. He then goes to retrieve it and, due to the loneliness he suffers from, decides to draw a face on it. He calls it "Wilson," the manufacturing company's name whose logo was on the ball. 
At first, Chuck speaks to the ball in a sarcastic manner. He maintains "critical distance" from it; He understands that Wilson is fictional and doesn't expect any real interaction with him. As time goes on however, Chuck starts to develop a real connection to Wilson. He sees Wilson as his companion through this isolation and loses all critical distance from him. He starts having full conversations with Wilson and almost drowns trying to retrieve Wilson when he floats away in the ocean. He is devastated by Wilson's loss and throws away his makeshift oars as a sign of surrender.

The film also has other subtleties that add to its overall atmosphere. One very interesting one is the whale that shows up when Noland leaves the island on his makeshift raft after being stranded there for over four years. Whales are usually a sign of solitude, but in the film, the whale is the first creature that Noland feels an emotional connection with in four years, and that shows when they make prolonged eye contact. This whale takes care of Noland and even saves his life by waking him up just in time for him to see the rescue boat passing by.

Another important sign is the pocket watch Kelly gives Chuck on Christmas. It belonged to her grandfather and helped him survive the southern pacific, which is exactly where Chuck's crash happens. The pocket watch (More importantly Kelly's photo in it) was a key part to his survival. It kept him little company, but he made the most of it and survived, bringing up the watch's "lifesaver" count to 2. 

The most important detail however is the angel wings logo on Dick and Bettina's ranch. The ranch is where the film begins ("ex nihilo") and where it ends. The logo was also on one of the packages that Chuck had with him on the island, and it is the only package that he left unopened for his entire 4 years there. Those angel wings can be seen as a sign of good and protection, and that is exactly what that package does to Chuck; It saves his life. When he makes it back to civilization, he finally delivers the package back to the ranch, along with a message that says "This package saved my life. Thank you." He held on to it with the hope that he can deliver it someday, and that gave him motivation to continue surviving.

When Chuck ends up stranded, his life is in the hands of nature. Nature is what feeds him, but it also injures and punishes him. Nature here is in binary opposition with itself; It is both Noland's guidance and his obstruction. Nature rewards him with coconuts from trees around him and marine life to feed him, but the same waves that bring him help also bring him harm. His first "Help" sign is washed away by the waves, and he is thrown by waves into a rock when he tries to leave the island for the first time, severely injuring his thighs.

Overall, the architecture and "Easter eggs" in Cast Away can have a separate movie explaining them all, and it is this attribute that makes Cast Away one of the greatest film I've ever seen.

It is a nod to Tom Hanks talent that for the majority of Cast Away the only other object or thing in the movie is a volleyball. I'm sure there will be wags who will glibly compare Cast Away to the likes of "Gilligan's Island" and "Survivor", but, in tone, approach, and overall accomplishment, this atypical Robinson Crusoe tale bears a strong resemblance to one of director Robert Zemeckis' earlier efforts, Contact. No, Cast Away isn't about space or messages from another planet, but, at its core, neither was Contact. Both films ask the same crucial existential question, one that Shakespeare pondered for years: taking all things into account, what does it mean to be human? How do we cope with loss, hopelessness, and isolation, and still find the courage to face the next day? The love and dream of a dead father sustained Jodie Foster's character in Contact. For Tom Hanks' Chuck Noland in Cast Away, it is the promise offered by the smile of his equally absent - and equally beloved - wife-to-be. A magical experience.

Tom Hanks performs alone for 80% of this film's runtime, which is an incredible feat. He's convincing as a man stranded for years with no human contact. 'Wilson the ball' is a nice touch too, helping further convey his deteriorating sanity.

The runtime, however, is a little too long, and the films pacing may not be for everyone. The first 20 minutes before the plane crash aren't that interesting either. If you're into deep character studies with a leisure pace(which I personally don't mind when done right), this may blow you away, but if you prefer things to be a little more condensed and brisk, you'll likely end up bored.

Cast Away is nonetheless a solid and unique movie anchored by Tom Hanks lead performance, and some beautiful cinematography.
